normal: It means the absence of diseases and infirmity, indicating the structure is normal.
clear: The lungs are clear and normal. No evidence for other diseases on lung.
sharp: This means that an anatomical structure's boundary or edge is clear and normal, meaning it is free of diseases.
sharply: Sharply seen means that an anatomical structure is clearly visible.
unremarkable: This represents some anatomical structures are normal, usually modifying cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes.
intact: The bonny structure is complete and normal, meaning no fractures.
stable: The modified anatomical structures are normal and stable. No evidence for diseases.
free: It usually refers to free air and is associate with pneumothorax,atelectasis,pneumoperitoneum and emphysema.
effusion: A pleural effusion is accumulation of excessive fluid in the pleural space, the potential space that surrounds each lung. A pleural effusion infiltrates the space between the visceral pleura and the parietal pleura
opacity: It is defined as an area of hazy opacification due to air displacement by fluid, airway collapse, fibrosis, or a neoplastic process. It is causes include infections, interstitial lung disease, and pulmonary edema.
pneumothorax: A pneumothorax is an abnormal collection of air in the pleural space between the lung and the chest wall. It may be caused by pneumonia or fibrosis and other diseases.
edema: Pulmonary edema, also known as pulmonary congestion, is excessive liquid accumulation in the tissue and air spaces of the lungs. It will show fluid in the alveolar walls
atelectasis: It is the collapse or closure of a lung resulting in reduced or absent gas exchange. Findings can include lung opacification and loss of lung volume.
tube: it is a surgical drain that is inserted through the chest wall and into the pleural space or the mediastinum to remove undesired substances such as air (pneumothorax), excess fluid (pleural effusion or hydrothorax), blood (hemothorax), chyle (chylothorax) or pus (empyema) from the intrathoracic space.
consolidation: it is a region of normally compressible lung tissue that has filled with liquid instead of air. Consolidation must be present to diagnose pneumonia: the signs of lobar pneumonia are characteristic and clinically referred to as consolidation.
process: Acute process' means there is abnormality in the anotomy structure.
abnormality: It means the exist of diseases and infirmity, indicating the structure is abnormal.
enlarge: It usually modifies cardiac silhouette and heart. Cardiomegaly is a medical condition in which the heart is enlarged.
tip: It refers to the top head of the tube.
low: The presence of low lung volumes may be a sign of a restrictive lung condition such as pulmonary fibrosis or sarcoidosis.
pneumonia: Pneumonia is an inflammatory condition of the lung primarily affecting the small air sacs known as alveoli.  Pneumonia may present with opacities. Complications such as pleural effusion may also be found increasing the diagnostic accuracy of lung consolidation and pleural effusion
line: It refers to venous access line ot PICC lines.
congestion: Pulmonary congestion is defined as accumulation of fluid in the lungs, resulting in impaired gas exchange and arterial hypoxemia.
catheter: catheter is a tube placed in the body to drain and collect urine from the bladder
cardiomegaly: Cardiomegaly (sometimes megacardia or megalocardia) is a medical condition in which the heart is enlarged.
fracture: fracture is a break in a rib bone.
air: It refers to the free air or gas in pleural space, indicating pneumothorax. Air displacement by fluid may lead to opacity.
tortuous: the Aorta is slightly tortuous. Sometimes it may refer to varicose veins
lead: It refers to the leading head of the tube.
disease: It means the exist of diseases and abnormalty, indicating the structure is abnormal.
calcification: Pulmonary calcification is a common asymptomatic finding. Pulmonary calcifications are caused mainly by two mechanisms: the dystrophic form and the metastatic form
prominence: It means the exist of some observation.
device: It refer to some equipments like picc tub, valve catheter, pacemaker hardware, arthroplastmarker icd defib, device support equipment and mediport'
engorgement: pulmonary vascular engorgement means obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the lung resulting in engorgement of pulmonary vessels
picc: A peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC), also called a PICC line, is a long, thin tube that's inserted through a vein in your arm and passed through to the larger veins near your heart.
clip: Surgical clips or vascular clips usually represent the one kind of medical equipments.
elevation: If tissues or anatomical structures are elevated, they are raised up higher than the normal location.
expand: It means the lungs are normally expanded and clear, indicating the absence of pneumothorax.
nodule: A lung nodule or pulmonary nodule is a relatively small focal density in the lung. it may be confused with the projection of a structure of the chest wall or skin, such as a nipple, a healing rib fracture or  lung cancer.
wire: sternotomis wires means the center line of the chest.
fluid: It refers to the water of liquid in the lung and it may indicate edema and other diseases.
degenerative: Degenerative disease is the result of a continuous process based on degenerative cell changes
pacemaker: pacemaker device usually represents the one kind of medical equipments.
thicken: Pleural thickening is an increase in the bulkiness of one or both of the pulmonary pleurae. It may cause by pulmonary Infection, empyema, tuberculosis or lung cancer.
marking: It represents interstitial markings or bronchovascular markings
scar: A scar (or scar tissue) is an area of fibrous tissue that replaces normal tissues after an injury.
hyperinflate: Hyperinflated lungs are larger-than-normal lungs as a result of trapped air.
blunt: Blunting of the costophrenic angles is usually caused by a pleural effusion, as already discussed. Other causes of costophrenic angle blunting include lung disease in the region of the costophrenic angle, and lung hyperexpansion.
loss: The etiology of lung volume loss can be listed as follows: airway obstruction or compression, obesity, scoliosis, restrictive diseases such as pulmonary fibrosis and interstitial lung disease, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, pleural effusions, rib injury (fractures or diaphragm paralysis), and heart failure
widen: The mediastinum is not widened or enlarged
collapse: collapse lung refers to pneumothorax or atelectasis.
density: The density (more precisely, the volumetric mass density; also known as specific mass), of a substance is its mass per unit volume.
emphysema: Emphysema, or pulmonary emphysema, is a lower respiratory tract disease, characterized by air-filled spaces (pneumatosis) in the lungs, that can vary in size and may be very large
aerate: Aeration (also called aerification or aeriation) is the process by which air is circulated through, mixed with or dissolved in a liquid or other substances that act as a fluid (such as soil).
mass: A lung mass is an abnormal growth or area in the lungs and it can also view as lung cancer.
crowd: Crowding of the bronchovascular structures is an important direct sign of volume loss. The atelectatic lung enhances densely after contrast administration because of closeness of the pulmonary arteries and arterioles within the collapsed lobe.
infiltrate: A pulmonary infiltrate is a substance denser than air, such as pus, blood, or protein, which lingers within the parenchyma of the lungs. Pulmonary infiltrates are associated with pneumonia, tuberculosis and sarcoidosis.
obscure: Some anatomy structures are not clear and is difficult to understand or see
deformity: It means some body parts are abnormal or unjuried.
hernia: Lung hernia (Sibson hernia) is a protrusion of lung outside of thoracic wall. the hernia is noted after chest trauma, thoracic surgery or certain pulmonary diseases
drainage: Tube drainage represents the one kind of medical equipment
distention: Distension generally refers to an enlargement, dilation, or ballooning effect. It may refer to: Abdominal distension,
shift: The mediastinal shift is the deviation of the mediastinal structures towards one side of the chest cavity, usually seen on chest radiograph. It indicates a severe asymmetry of intrathoracic pressures.
stent: tracheal stent represents the one kind of medical equipments
pressure: Pulmonary venous pressure is intermediate between mean PAP and LAP over all physiologic pressures
lesion: Lung nodules, pulmonary nodules, white spots, lesions these terms all describe the same phenomenon: an abnormality in the lungs.
finding: Some observation on body parts, usually indicating abnormalty.
borderline: borderline size of the cardiac silhouette means the cardiac silhouette is not enlarged and normal.
hardware: It represents the one kind of medical equipments.
dilation: the state of being larger or more open than normal
chf: Heart failure sometimes known as congestive heart failure occurs when the heart muscle doesn't pump blood as well as it should. When this happens, blood often backs up and fluid can build up in the lungs, causing shortness of breath.
redistribution: If the pulmonary edema is due to heart failure or fluid overload, you may also see cardiomegaly and distension of the pulmonary veins, particularly in the upper lung fields.
aspiration: Aspiration pneumonia occurs when food or liquid is breathed into the airways or lungs, instead of being swallowed.
excluded_obs: Some observations that seldom appear in the reports.
covid19: It is a contagious disease caused by a virus. Ground-glass opacities, consolidation, thickening, pleural effusions commonly appear in infection.
hypoexpansion basal: Hypoexpansion basal refers to the insufficient expansion of the lower (basal) parts of the lungs. It's often due to conditions that limit lung expansion such as atelectasis, pleural effusion, or fibrosis. It can lead to reduced gas exchange and potential respiratory distress.
non axial articular degenerative changes: Non axial articular degenerative changes refer to the progressive deterioration or wear and tear of joint surfaces that are not located along the central axis of the body. This can include joints in the limbs, often resulting in conditions such as osteoarthritis.
multiple nodules: "Multiple nodules" refers to the presence of more than one small abnormal tissue growths or lumps in the body. In the context of medicine, it's often used to describe findings in the lungs, thyroid, or other organs during imaging studies. These nodules can be benign or malignant.
COPD signs: COPD signs refer to the observable indications of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, a chronic inflammatory lung disease. These signs may include difficulty breathing, cough, mucus (sputum) production and wheezing, due to longterm exposure to irritating gases or particulate matter, most often from cigarette smoke.
mediastinal shift: A mediastinal shift is a shift of the central thoracic structures (heart, great vessels, trachea) towards one side of the chest. It is often a sign of significant disease or injury such as tension pneumothorax or lung collapse.
hiatal hernia: A hiatal hernia occurs when the upper part of your stomach bulges through the large muscle separating your abdomen and chest (diaphragm). It is usually asymptomatic but can lead to discomfort and conditions like acid reflux.
central venous catheter: A central venous catheter is a tube that's placed into a patient's large vein, typically in the neck, chest, or groin. It's used to give medications, fluids, nutrients, or blood products over a long period of time. It can also be used for collecting blood samples for testing.
ground glass pattern: A "ground glass" pattern refers to a radiology finding in the lungs, where parts of the lungs appear hazy or foggy, but without obscuring the underlying structures. This pattern can be indicative of various lung conditions, including inflammation, fibrosis, or earlystage pneumonia.
surgery lung: "Surgery lung" is not a standard medical term. However, it may refer to postoperative pulmonary complications, such as pneumonia, atelectasis, or acute respiratory distress syndrome that occur after surgery, particularly thoracic surgery.
miliary opacities: Miliary opacities refer to numerous small (13mm) nodules distributed throughout the lung fields, often due to hematogenous spread of an infection or malignancy. The term is derived from the resemblance to millet seeds on imaging.
sclerotic bone lesion: A sclerotic bone lesion is an area of bone that has become hardened or increased in density. This usually results from conditions such as osteoporosis, metastatic cancer, or infections. These lesions can often be seen on radiographic images as areas of increased bone density.
pleural plaques: Pleural plaques are areas of fibrous thickening on the pleura (the lining of the lungs). They are primarily caused by exposure to asbestos and typically indicate a prior asbestos exposure. They are usually benign and asymptomatic.
osteosynthesis material: Osteosynthesis material refers to medical devices used to fixate and stabilize fractured bones during the healing process. This can include metal plates, screws, and rods, often made of stainless steel or titanium. These materials are used in surgical procedures to promote bone healing and recovery.
calcified mediastinal adenopathy: Calcified mediastinal adenopathy refers to the presence of calcified lymph nodes in the mediastinum, the area between the lungs. This can occur due to various conditions like previous infections or malignancies. The calcification is often picked up on imaging studies such as CT scans.
apical pleural thickening: Apical pleural thickening refers to the thickening of the pleura (the protective layers of tissue that line the lungs and the inside of the chest cavity) at the apex, or upper part, of the lungs. It's often due to inflammation, infection, or exposure to asbestos.
aortic elongation: Aortic elongation refers to the abnormal lengthening or distortion of the aorta, the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body. It can be due to aging, hypertension, or certain genetic conditions.
major fissure thickening: Major fissure thickening refers to the enlargement or swelling of the major fissure in the lungs. This can be caused by various conditions, including infection, inflammation, or disease. It may be associated with lung diseases like emphysema or lung cancer.
callus rib fracture: A callus rib fracture refers to the healing process of a broken rib where new bone (callus) forms around the fracture. It's a sign of bone remodeling and typically observed in radiographic examinations a few weeks after the fracture occurred.
cervical rib: A cervical rib is an extra rib that forms above the first rib, growing from the base of the neck just above the collarbone. It's a congenital condition, present from birth, and can cause discomfort and complications if it compresses nearby nerves and blood vessels.
loculated pleural effusion: A loculated pleural effusion is a complication in which pockets of fluid become trapped within the pleural space, the area between the lung and the chest wall. These pockets, or loculations, are typically caused by inflammation or infection that leads to pleural thickening or adhesion.
flattened diaphragm: A flattened diaphragm is a medical condition where the domeshaped muscle at the base of the lungs, which aids in breathing, becomes lowered or flat. This condition often occurs in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to hyperinflation of the lungs.
pulmonary artery hypertension: Pulmonary artery hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of your heart. It can lead to shortness of breath, dizziness, and other symptoms, and can be serious if not managed properly.
tracheal shift: Tracheal shift is a medical condition where the trachea moves from its normal position in the neck. This can be caused by conditions such as pneumothorax or pleural effusion which increase pressure on one side of the chest, pushing the trachea to the opposite side.
pulmonary fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis is a lung disease that occurs when lung tissue becomes damaged and scarred, making it difficult for your lungs to work effectively. It can result from a variety of causes, including longterm exposure to certain toxins, medical conditions, radiation therapy, and certain medications.
mediastinal mass: A mediastinal mass is an abnormal growth within the mediastinum, the cavity that separates the lungs from the rest of the chest. It can be benign or malignant and can cause compression of vital structures like the heart and airways.
suture material: Suture material refers to specialized threads used in surgery to hold body tissues together after an injury or surgery. It can be absorbable or non-absorbable, and monofilament or multifilament, depending on the intended use and tissue type.
sternotomy: A sternotomy is a surgical procedure that involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to gain access to the heart and lungs. It's often performed for heart surgery, such as coronary artery bypass grafting or heart valve repair or replacement.
supra aortic elongation: Supra aortic elongation refers to the abnormal lengthening or stretching of the arteries that originate from the aortic arch, which is the part of the aorta located above the heart. It can be related to conditions like atherosclerosis or Marfan syndrome.
metal: In medical imaging, "metal" refers to the presence of metallic objects or implants within the body. These can be seen on radiographs as opaque, bright white areas. This can include surgical hardware, dental fillings, or swallowed objects. They might interfere with imaging results.
abnormal foreign body: "Abnormal foreign body" refers to an object originating outside the body that has been accidentally introduced into the body. This can occur through inhalation, ingestion, or penetration of the skin. These foreign bodies can cause various complications depending on their size, location, and nature.
central venous catheter via jugular vein: A central venous catheter via jugular vein is a procedure where a long, thin tube (catheter) is inserted into the jugular vein, typically in the neck, to provide access to the large central veins near the heart. This allows for medication delivery, blood sampling, and fluid administration.
vertebral anterior compression: Vertebral anterior compression refers to a type of vertebral fracture where the front part of the vertebra collapses, causing the vertebra to compress or squash. This can result in back pain, limited mobility, or height loss. It's commonly caused by osteoporosis or trauma.
diaphragmatic eventration: Diaphragmatic eventration refers to an abnormal elevation of the diaphragm. It's a congenital or acquired condition characterized by abnormal contour of the diaphragm, usually involving a significant portion of it. This could lead to respiratory distress.
calcified densities: Calcified densities refer to the hardened deposits usually of calcium that show up on imaging scans as brighter spots. They can occur in various tissues and organs, often indicating a previous or ongoing inflammation, infection, or presence of certain diseases.
volume loss: Volume loss refers to the reduction in the size or mass of lung tissue, often due to conditions like atelectasis or fibrosis. This could lead to decreased lung capacity and impaired gas exchange. It is often detected via radiographic imaging.
single chamber device: A single chamber device is a type of pacemaker, an electronic device that regulates the heartbeat. This device has one lead that connects the pacemaker to one chamber of the heart, typically the right ventricle. It helps control abnormal heart rhythms by sending electrical pulses to the heart.
vertebral compression: Vertebral compression refers to a fracture or collapse of a vertebra, usually due to osteoporosis, that can cause pain, height loss, or spinal deformity. It is often associated with aging and characterized by decreased bone strength.
bullas: Bullas, or pulmonary bullae, are abnormal air spaces in the lungs, typically associated with emphysema. They are characterized by thin walls and can be a result of damage to lung tissue. They can cause breathing difficulties and may lead to pneumothorax if they rupture.
axial hyperostosis: Axial hyperostosis is a condition characterized by excessive bone growth along the axis of the skeleton, particularly in the spine and collar bone. It can cause pain, stiffness, and restricted movement. It is often associated with syndromes like diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH).
aortic button enlargement: Aortic button enlargement refers to the widening or enlarging of the aortic root, the portion of the aorta closest to and connected with the heart. This may be due to conditions like aortic aneurysm or atherosclerosis. It can be seen in chest X-rays or CT scans.
calcified granuloma: A calcified granuloma is a small area of inflammation in tissue, often in the lungs, that has calcified over time. This usually occurs after an infection or other disease has resolved, and it often indicates a past, not current, health problem.
clavicle fracture: A clavicle fracture is a break in the collarbone, one of the main bones in the shoulder. This type of fracture is often caused by a direct blow to the shoulder and can result in severe pain and difficulty moving the affected arm.
dual chamber device: A dual chamber device, often referring to a pacemaker or defibrillator, is a medical device that monitors and regulates both the atrium and ventricle of the heart. It helps to ensure proper heart rhythm by sending electrical impulses to both chambers.
mediastinic lipomatosis: Mediastinal lipomatosis is a condition characterized by an excessive amount of fat accumulation in the mediastinum, the space in the chest between the lungs that contains the heart, esophagus, trachea, and several other organs. It is often associated with obesity or long-term steroid use.
esophagic dilatation: Esophageal dilatation is the enlargement or stretching of the esophagus. It often results from conditions that obstruct or disrupt the normal function of the esophagus, such as achalasia or esophageal stricture. Symptoms may include difficulty swallowing and regurgitation of food.
azygoesophageal recess shift: The azygoesophageal recess shift refers to the lateral displacement of the azygoesophageal line, typically seen in chest X-rays. This shift is often indicative of various diseases, such as lung collapse, mass effect, or pleural effusion.
breast mass: A breast mass is an abnormal lump or swelling in the breast tissue. It can be benign (non-cancerous) like fibroadenomas or malignant (cancerous) like breast cancer. Both require medical evaluation for proper diagnosis and treatment.
round atelectasis: Round atelectasis, also known as folded lung or Blesovsky's syndrome, is a form of atelectasis where the lung collapses and folds onto itself. It is typically associated with pleural diseases causing chronic effusion, such as asbestosis. It appears as a rounded mass on a chest radiograph.
surgery humeral: "Surgery humeral" refers to any surgical procedure performed on the humerus, the long bone in the upper arm or forelimb that runs from the shoulder to the elbow. This could include fracture repair, joint replacement, or tumor removal.
aortic aneurysm: An aortic aneurysm is an abnormal bulge that occurs in the wall of the major blood vessel (aorta) that carries blood from your heart to your body. Aneurysms can occur anywhere along the aorta, but are most common in the abdominal region.
nephrostomy tube: A nephrostomy tube is a catheter inserted through the skin and into the kidney to drain urine. It's often used when a blockage prevents normal urine flow. The tube allows urine to bypass the blocked part of the urinary tract, providing relief from symptoms and preventing kidney damage.
sternoclavicular junction hypertrophy: Sternoclavicular junction hypertrophy refers to the abnormal enlargement or overgrowth of the junction where the sternum (breastbone) meets the clavicle (collarbone). This can be due to various conditions, including arthritis, infection, or malignancy.
pleural mass: A pleural mass is a growth or tumor located on the pleura, the membrane surrounding the lungs. It can be benign or malignant and may be caused by various conditions including lung cancer, mesothelioma, or pleural metastases from other cancers.
empyema: Empyema refers to a condition where pus collects in the pleural space, which is the area between the lungs and the inner surface of the chest wall. It's usually caused by a bacterial infection and often occurs as a complication of pneumonia.
external foreign body: An "external foreign body" refers to any object originating outside the body that is unintentionally introduced into the body. This could occur due to ingestion, inhalation, or penetration through the skin or natural orifices. These can cause various complications depending on their location and nature.
respiratory distress: Respiratory distress refers to difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. It can be caused by various conditions such as asthma, pneumonia, or COPD. Symptoms include rapid breathing, chest pain or discomfort, and restlessness or anxiety.
total atelectasis: Total atelectasis, also known as lung collapse, is the complete deflation of the entire lung. It can be caused by a blocked airway or by pressure on the outside of the lung. Symptoms include chest pain, cough, and shortness of breath.
ventriculoperitoneal drain tube: A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) drain tube is a medical device that relieves pressure on the brain caused by fluid accumulation. It is implanted within the brain ventricles and drains excess cerebrospinal fluid into the peritoneal cavity, where it is reabsorbed.
right sided aortic arch: A "right sided aortic arch" is a rare congenital anomaly where the aorta descends in the right chest instead of the left. It may be associated with heart defects and can affect the flow of blood through the heart.
aortic endoprosthesis: An aortic endoprosthesis is a device implanted within the aorta, the main artery of the body, to treat conditions such as aneurysms or dissections. It's typically used in minimally invasive procedures to strengthen the aorta's weak spots.
cyst: A cyst is a closed sac-like structure that can be filled with fluid, pus, or other material. Cysts can occur anywhere in the body, under the skin or within organs. They may be harmless and require no treatment, or they might need to be drained or surgically removed.
pulmonary venous hypertension: Pulmonary venous hypertension is a medical condition characterized by high blood pressure in the vessels that carry blood from the lungs to the heart. It's often due to left-sided heart diseases and can lead to shortness of breath and other symptoms.
double J stent: A double J stent is a thin tube inserted into the ureter to prevent or treat obstruction of urine flow from the kidney. It is named so because of its shape that resembles the letter "J" at both ends.
